intro: Polygala kurdica subsp. kurdica, commonly known as the Kurdish milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and compound leaves with a slightly hairy texture. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are usually pink or purple in color, blooming from late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or limestone-rich habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
